\\ %text In \[ R = \int_0^{\frac\pi{2}}\underbrace{(2\log\sin x - \log\sin 2x)}_\beta\cdot dx \], \[ \qquad \beta = \log f(x) - \log g(x) - \log 2\].
\underline\text{ But what are $f(x)$ and $g(x)$}? %

\\ %text Given that
\[ 2\log\sin x - \log\sin 2x = \log\sin x-\log\cos x - \log 2\]
\underline\text{would the following be true?} %
\\ %text Given the results of Step 2, what will $2R = R+R$ - and therefore - $R$ equal? %

reason.tex:
%text There is a nice, little rule that says \[\qquad \int_0^a f(x)\cdot dx = \int_0^a f(a-x)\cdot dx \]
Which means that % \begin{align} &R = \int_0^{\frac\pi{2}}\left[ \log \sin x - \log \cos x - \log 2\right]\cdot dx \\ &= \int_0^{\frac\pi{2}}\left[ \log \sin\left(\frac\pi{2}-x\right) - \log \cos\left(\frac\pi{2}-x\right) - \log 2\right]dx\\ &= \int_0^{\frac\pi{2}}\left[ \log\cos x - \log \sin x -\log 2\right]dx \end{align}
